page.title: 03THE PACKHORSE BRIDGE,SUTTON
page.content: {The ford and Packhorse Bridge}form one of the most picturesque scenes in the village.They provide a crossing place on one of the tributaries of the River Ivel.The ford is a crossing place for motor vehicles.It is passable at most times,though following prolonged or very heavy periods of rain,it is best avoided.The Packhorse Bridge dates back to the early 14th century,the dating being made possible by the shape of the two arches and the type of stonework found on the parapet. The bridge is used by cyclists and pedestrians and there are passing places built into the walls on either side.It is the only bridge of its kind in Bedfordshire and is therefore very popular amongst historians and artists and articles and sketches often appear in local magazines.A"tug-of-war"is held annually through the ford.
